title: Need some help with creating a simple USB stick.

forumNotes.author: HHawk
forumNotes.content:
Can someone tell me which program is the easiest to use to create a "simple" USB stick which is bootable and contains the following:  

1. Ubuntu 10.10 or 10.04 Trial-version (trying Ubuntu without installing)  
2. Windows Recovery Disc both x64 version \*  
3. Windows Recovery Disc both x86 version \*  
4. MemTest86+  
5. Ultimate Boot CD v5.03  

On a different note; instead of using an .iso version, is it possible to unpack the ubuntu.iso? If yes, would this speed up the loading times?  

I already tried several programs like MultiBootISOs (2.1.4.0), but somehow it won't work. I am getting file not found errors, non-booting programs and blinking cursors... Sigh.  

The biggest chance is, is that I am to stupid to create a working USB stick with these programs...  

\* These are the recovery discs I mean: [http://neosmart.net/...m-repair-discs/](http://neosmart.net/blog/2009/windows-7-system-repair-discs/ "External link")

forumNotes.author: steve6375
forumNotes.content:
How many systems have you tried to boot it on?  

It may be your BIOS rather than anything 'wrong' with what you have done.  

If you only have one system, you can always try Qemu Manager and try booting in a virtual machine from the USB stick - see [http://sites.google....ls/qemu-manager](http://sites.google.com/site/rmprepusb/tutorials/qemu-manager "External link")  

For booting the recovery disks - it would be easier/simpler if you could make an ISO of these and then boot from the ISO file - see [http://www.boot-land...?showtopic=7916](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=7916 "External link")  

For Ubuntu, I don't have any direct experience, but Ylmf is based on Ubuntu and so should be similar - see the last bit of this page for how to boot to Ylmf iso with a persistent file system. [http://sites.google..../tutorials/ylmf](http://sites.google.com/site/rmprepusb/tutorials/ylmf "External link")  

For memtest86 - assuming you change the name/folder accordingly then to the grub4dos menu.lst file add...  

title MEMTEST  
kernel /boot/memtest86.bin

forumNotes.author: HHawk
forumNotes.content:
Thanks for the answer.  

The booting works, I get the boot menu, but I am getting the problems described at the 4th paragraph (blinking cursors, files not found, etc.)  

The link I included shows the Recovery Discs already in .iso format. :S  
...or should I make an .iso from an .iso.....?  

Anyways, I will look more into it, by giving it one more chance, otherwise I had enough. Been busy with this crap for the past 2 weeks without any results. It's giving me headache and I am getting really frustrated... Sigh...

forumNotes.author: steve6375
forumNotes.content:
If you have them as ISOs then  

1. Download RMPrepUSB (see my sig)  
2. Partition a USB drive as FAT32+HDD+MSDOS  
3. Run Install grub4dos  
4. Copy iso files to USB  
5. Create a menu.lst as in the post I gave before - duplicate the entries for 2nd iso  

Try option 1 or 3 from grub4dos menu

Hi Wonko... Thanks for your uplifting answer. :smile:  

I am just getting frustrated cause I don't know what I am doing, I followed several tutorials on how to install grub4dos (which I am failing). And when trying to use MultiBootIso, the USB stick is working fine, but programs aren't working (= booting).  

I am going to give it a new go with multibootiso, cause that seems the most easiest way for me to install grub4dos on a USB bootstick and making it 100% bootable. Hopefully I will get a result this time.  

//edit \& update  

Maybe I misread, but is there a clear tutorial on how to install grub4dos on a USB stick? I did several searches on this forum (and on Google) but the only tutorial(s) I seem to find are the ones which are telling how to load / run an .iso or how to map them and stuff... :S   

**Edited by HHawk, 22 November 2010 - 02:33 PM.**

forumNotes.author: steve6375
forumNotes.content: RMPrepUSB is what you want. It will partition your USB stick correctly (use HDD option for best compatibility) and then just click on the Install grub4dos button - EASY! ![:hi:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/hi.gif)

forumNotes.author: HHawk
forumNotes.content: Okay thanks for the answer, will give it a go and try it out. I will report back if I run into problems (most probably) and I will also report back when I get it working (unlikely lol).

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
> Maybe I misread, but is there a clear tutorial on how to install grub4dos on a USB stick? I did several searches on this forum (and on Google) but the only tutorial(s) I seem to find are the ones which are telling how to load / run an .iso or how to map them and stuff... :S * **Forget** MultiBootIso (whatever it is and whatever it does) * **Forget** ANYTHING you may have read here and there, for the moment trust us, EVERYTHING needed is here on boot-land * Re-partition/re-format the stick with RMPREPUSB: [http://www.boot-land...?showtopic=7739](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=7739 "External link") [http://sites.google....site/rmprepusb/](http://sites.google.com/site/rmprepusb/ "External link") (remember to choose to install grub4dos) * **OR** : install it "normally". If you simply read the guide: [http://www.boot-land...?showtopic=5187](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=5187 "External link") AND the stickies in the grub4dos Forum: [http://www.boot-land...hp?showforum=66](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showforum=66 "External link") (the guide also is a sticky)
you should have NO problems whatsoever, unless there are problems in your partitioning/formatting, that's why starting from scratch with RMPREPUSB is advised. If EVEN RMPREPUSB gives you problems, you can try the other options available (sticky in this SAME forum): [http://www.boot-land...?showtopic=9460](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=9460 "External link") VERIFY you have a recommended grub4dos version (AGAIN, sticky in the grub4dos forum): [http://www.boot-land...hp?showtopic=14](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=14 "External link") ![:hi:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/hi.gif) Wonko

I think I read to much on different websites telling all something different which resulted in a non-working USB stick. And giving me so much frustration. :S 3. I will go for the option (RMPREPUSB) seems to be good enough for what I want. I installed RMPREPUSB v.2.1.600 and I am presented with a GUI. I selected the correct USB stick and already selected Boot as HDD (as directed by steve6375), do I need to check anything else? E.g. FAT32? And what about Boot type? WinPE, etc? Or just click on Install grub4dos? **Edited by HHawk, 22 November 2010 - 02:51 PM.**

forumNotes.author: steve6375
forumNotes.content:
Set the items 1-5 and click on 6 Prepare Drive to wipe, partition and format your stick.  
When that has finished click on Install grub4dos.  

Settings 1 - 5 are  
1. MAX  
2. any name you like (volume label)  
3. MSDOS will do  
4. FAT32 + HDD  
5. leave unticked  
6. Click to format  

Then after doing grub4dos, copy over your recovery ISO files.  
Then create a menu.lst  

So Stick should have  

menu.lst  
grldr (copied on when you use Install grub4dos button)  
iso1  
iso2

forumNotes.author: HHawk
forumNotes.content:
Okay, well I still seem to have problems; I am getting the GRUB menu, but I did get that before. The first problem is with MemTest86+ - I am still getting a blinking cursor after I select it from the GRUB menu. Here is my menu.lst entry: > title Memtest86+ > find --set-root /mt410.iso > map --mem /mt410.iso (hd32) > map --hook > root (hd32) > chainloader (hd32) Also I am experiencing problems with Ultimate Boot CD V5.0.3. Though I get the UBCD menu (after selecting it in the GRUB menu), but after selecting a program, it gives me an error upon loading a tool / program. I don't understand why this is, cause it should work right? I downloaded the original .iso from the UBCD website. Here is my menu.lst entry: > title Ultimate Boot CD v5.0.3 > find --set-root /ubcd503.iso > map --heads=0 --sectors-per-track=0 /ubcd503.iso (hd32) > map --hook > root (hd32) > chainloader (hd32) The positive notes; the Recovery Discs for both Vista (x86 and x64) and Windows 7 (x86 and x64) now do work without problems. So that's good.
A different question is it possible to add / display a horizontal rule in the GRUB menu? Like this for example: > Windows Recovery Tools > ------------------------------- (horizontal rule) > Win 7 Recovery x86 > Win 7 Recovery x64 > Win Vista Recovery x86 > Win Vista Recovery x64 > > (2 empty lines) > > Troubleshooting Tools > ------------------------------- (horizontal rule) > MemTest86+ > Ultimate Boot CD V5.0.3 > > (2 empty lines) > > Various Other Tools > ------------------------------- (horizontal rule) > Ubuntu 10.10 **Edited by HHawk, 23 November 2010 - 08:10 AM.**

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
You have a "queer" sense of priorities. :smile: You have a less-then-half working thing and you are "preoccupied" about menu separators? :smile: For memtest+86, use the .bin: [http://www.memtest.org/](http://www.memtest.org/ "External link") [http://www.memtest.o...est86 -4.10.zip](http://www.memtest.org/download/4.10/memtest86+-4.10.zip "External link") Example: ``` title Memtest86+ find --set-root /memtest86+.bin kernel /memtest86+.bin ```

For UBCD, see if THIS is the issue: [http://www.boot-land...?...c=7312\&st=7](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=7312&st=7 "External link") About the separator, you can create an UNbootable entry: [http://www.boot-land...?...=6119\&st=72](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=6119&st=72 "External link") :smile: Wonko

forumNotes.author: HHawk
forumNotes.content:
Yeah Dutch people always work in a strange way. :smile:  

I managed to get UBCD working thanks to you. I unpacked it and edited the menu.lst like this:  

> title Ultimate Boot CD v5.0.3  
> find --set-root /grldr  
> configfile /ubcd/menus/grub4dos/main.lst

However memtest86+ is still being a pain. I downloaded the .bin and added it to my menu.lst like this:  

> title Memtest86+  
> find --set-root /memtest86+.bin  
> kernel /memtest86+.bin

But this gives me error 28: selected item cannot fit into memory?  
Any ideas?  

The spaces / seperator work perfectly! Thanks.

>

forumNotes.author: steve6375
forumNotes.content:
All of the menu items below work (in my system) - can you try on your system? title memtest86+-4.10.bin find --set-root /memtest86+-4.10.bin kernel /memtest86+-4.10.bin title memtest86+-4.10.bin find --set-root /memtest86+-4.10.bin kernel --type=linux /memtest86+-4.10.bin title memtest86+-4.10.bin find --set-root /memtest86+-4.10.bin kernel --no-mem-option /memtest86+-4.10.bin title memtest.img (memtest.img obtained from ISO) find --set-root /memtest.img map /memtest.img (fd0) map --hook chainloader (fd0)+1 rootnoverify (fd0) map --floppies=1
HTH S

forumNotes.author: HHawk
forumNotes.content:
> All of the menu items below work (in my system) - can you try on your system? > > title memtest86+-4.10.bin > find --set-root /memtest86+-4.10.bin > kernel /memtest86+-4.10.bin > > title memtest86+-4.10.bin > find --set-root /memtest86+-4.10.bin > kernel --type=linux /memtest86+-4.10.bin > > title memtest86+-4.10.bin > find --set-root /memtest86+-4.10.bin > kernel --no-mem-option /memtest86+-4.10.bin > > title memtest.img (memtest.img obtained from ISO) > find --set-root /memtest.img > map /memtest.img (fd0) > map --hook > chainloader (fd0)+1 > rootnoverify (fd0) > map --floppies=1 > >
> > HTH > S
The last option works without problems! :smile: ...the one with the .img. Thnx!
